item.title: VSCode on the Cloud
item.description: Goal Using Google Cloud Platform, host an instance of VSCode to access via the browser for ~$25-$50/month. More specifically, we’ll be hosting an instance of Code-Server on GCP in a constantly-running VM. This works as an alternative to the cloud-development environments which may limit the developer in some way: Number of private repositories Working Hours in a given period Number of projects Repository integration. Requirements This tutorial assumes you have already set up a GCP account and enabled billing.

item.title: Run VSCode in the Browser
item.description: As a ChromeOS user, it’s not uncommon to find that most Linux programs don’t run as smoothly as one would hope. If there’s a version that runs in the browser, it’s likely to be a better experience. Enter code-server. While its primary intention is to be run on the cloud as a server-based IDE, they provide builds which you can run locally. Releases: https://github.com/cdr/code-server/releases Move tar file to the linux container.

item.title: Installing Python on ChromeOS
item.description: The use of each software being installed: pyenv - install and manage different versions of python pipenv - manage the different development environments you may need to use in the future. Usecase: you have a project that requires Dependency A v1, and another that required Dep A v2. You can’t have both installed onyour device. Use environments. Pipenv makes it easy to use virtual environments and pip together at one time.

item.title: SFTP Server Setup
item.description: Assuming the user has already created a VM with a static IP address open to HTTP/S traffic… SSH into the VM which you’d like to turn into a SFTP server. Create a new account which you’d like to provide to users to deposit files: sudo adduser username sudo passwd username Create the sftp directory and limit the user’s access and permissions. Change the username appropriately: sudo mkdir -p /var/sftp/uploads sudo chown root:root /var/sftp sudo chmod 755 /var/sftp sudo chown username:username /var/sftp/uploads Enable client authentication in the ssh config file:

item.title: GCP VM Setup for Squid Proxy and SFTP
Squid Proxy Server Setup
item.description: These instructions assume you have successfully completed the following: Opened a GCP account. Set up a VM with a static IP address and open HTTP/HTTPS ports. The goal of these instrctions is to create a functional proxy VM on GCP. Setting up the port rules: With you VM already created and tagged correctly, navigate to VPC Network > Firewall Rules. Here, a number of networking rules have been created.
